focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: First, solve for <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></math>. Subtract 6 from both sides of <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math> to get <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. The question asks for the value of <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Substitute 12 for <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi></math> to get <math><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for shortcuts. Instead of solving for x completely (x=3), notice that you can solve directly for the term 4x.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>g</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mn>2</mn></math> for <math><mi>x</mi></math> in the function definition: <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Calculating the exponent gives <math><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, which equals <math><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When evaluating functions, carefully perform exponentiation before addition according to the order of operations.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A printing machine can print 60 pages in 5 minutes. At this rate, how many minutes will it take the machine to print 240 pages?
questions.explanation: Calculate the rate per minute: <math><mfrac><mn>60</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> pages per minute. To print 240 pages, divide the total pages by the rate: <math><mfrac><mn>240</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math> minutes.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Find the unit rate (per 1 unit) first, then multiply or divide to find the target value.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='50' y='50' width='200' height='100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='150' y='40' text-anchor='middle'>Length = 12</text><text x='260' y='100' text-anchor='start'>Width = 5</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A rectangle with length labeled 12 and width labeled 5.
questions.question: A rectangle has a length of 12 meters and a width of 5 meters. What is the area, in square meters, of the rectangle?
questions.explanation: The area of a rectangle is calculated as <math><mtext>length</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>width</mtext></math>. Thus, <math><mn>12</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> square meters.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Don't confuse perimeter (adding sides) with area (multiplying length and width).

questions.question: The population of a bacterial colony is modeled by the function <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1.04</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, where <math><mi>t</mi></math> is the time in hours after the initial observation. Which statement is the best interpretation of the number 2,500 in this context?

options.A: The population increases by 2,500 bacteria each hour.
options.B: The population increases by 2,500% each hour.
options.C: The estimated initial population of the colony.
options.D: The estimated population of the colony after 1 hour.

questions.explanation: In an exponential function of the form <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi></msup></math>, the value <math><mi>a</mi></math> represents the initial value when <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Here, 2,500 is the initial population when <math><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In exponential models, identify the coefficient 'a' as the starting value (y-intercept) and the base 'b' as the growth/decay factor.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add the two equations together: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. This simplifies to <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>21</mn></math>. Dividing by 3 gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When coefficients of a variable are opposites (like +y and -y), adding the equations is the most efficient method.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='60' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='60' y1='250' x2='60' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='220' y='290' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>Age of Car (Years)</text><text x='20' y='135' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle' transform='rotate(-90 20,135)'>Price ($1,000s)</text><line x1='55' y1='66' x2='60' y2='66' stroke='black'/><text x='50' y='70' font-family='Arial' font-size='10' text-anchor='end'>10</text><line x1='55' y1='250' x2='60' y2='250' stroke='black'/><text x='45' y='255' font-family='Arial' font-size='10' text-anchor='end'>0</text><circle cx='80' cy='90' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='100' cy='110' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='140' cy='130' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='160' cy='150' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='200' cy='180' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='230' cy='200' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><circle cx='280' cy='230' r='3' fill='#4A90E2'/><line x1='60' y1='66' x2='300' y2='258' stroke='#E74C3C' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot measuring 'Age of Car' on the x-axis and 'Price' on the y-axis. The data points start high on the y-axis at 10 and trend downwards to the right, indicating a negative relationship. A red dashed line of best fit passes through the y-intercept at 10 and slopes downward.
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows the relationship between the age of a car in years, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, and its current resale price in thousands of dollars, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>. Which equation best represents the line of best fit shown?
questions.explanation:
We can identify the correct equation by analyzing the slope and y-intercept of the line of best fit.

1. Identify the Slope Direction:
The line goes down from left to right. This indicates a negative slope (as age increases, price decreases). This eliminates options A and C, which have positive slopes.


2. Identify the Y-Intercept:
The line crosses the vertical y-axis (where x=0) at the value 10. This means the y-intercept is positive 10. In the equation y=mx+b, this corresponds to b=10.

Option B is the only choice with a negative slope (-0.8) and a positive y-intercept (+10).
questions.score_improvement_tip: When matching a graph to an equation <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, always do two quick checks: 1) Is the line going up (+) or down (-)? 2) Does it cross the y-axis above (+) or below (-) zero?

questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 18 to both sides: <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. Divide by 2: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Take the square root: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The positive solution is 3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that quadratic equations often have two solutions. Pay attention if the question asks specifically for the 'positive' one.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M 100,250 L 300,250 L 200,50 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='140' y1='145' x2='160' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='240' y1='155' x2='260' y2='145' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 190,70 Q 200,80 210,70' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='200' y='35' font-family='Arial' font-size='16' text-anchor='middle'>C</text><text x='90' y='265' font-family='Arial' font-size='16' text-anchor='end'>A</text><text x='310' y='265' font-family='Arial' font-size='16' text-anchor='start'>B</text><text x='200' y='95' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>50°</text><text x='140' y='245' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>x°</text><text x='260' y='245' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A triangle labeled ABC with vertex C at the top. Tick marks on sides AC and BC indicate they are equal in length. An angle arc at vertex C is labeled 50°. Angle arcs at base vertices A and B are both labeled x°.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, the sides <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> are equal in length, and the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>50</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
We can solve for x by using the properties of isosceles triangles.

Step 1: Identify the Base Angles
Since AC=BC, Triangle ABC is an isosceles triangle. The Isosceles Triangle Theorem states that the angles opposite the equal sides are also equal. Therefore, ∠A=∠B=x.

Step 2: Use the Sum of Angles
The sum of angles in any triangle is always 180°.
50°+x+x=180°
50+2x=180

Step 3: Solve for x
Subtract 50 from both sides:
2x=130
Divide by 2:
x=65
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for tick marks on the sides of a triangle. If two sides are equal, the angles opposite those sides are automatically equal. This is often the 'hidden' information you need to solve the equation.

questions.question: The equation <math><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>200</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mi>h</mi></math> gives the total earnings <math><mi>E</mi></math>, in dollars, of a musician for a performance lasting <math><mi>h</mi></math> hours. Which equation correctly expresses <math><mi>h</mi></math> in terms of <math><mi>E</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: To isolate <math><mi>h</mi></math>, subtract 200 from both sides: <math><mi>E</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>200</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn><mi>h</mi></math>. Then divide by 15: <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>200</mn></mrow><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use inverse operations in reverse order of operations (PEMDAS) to isolate a variable.

questions.question_chart_description: The chart displays the graph of the rational function f(x) = 1/x + 4. The y-axis acts as a vertical asymptote at x = 0. A horizontal asymptote is visible at y = 4, indicated by a dashed red line.
questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is the result of shifting the graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> to the right by <math><mn>3</mn></math> units. Which equation defines function <math><mi>g</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To shift the graph of a function horizontally, we modify the input variable x. The transformation rule states that to shift a function f(x) to the right by k units, we evaluate f(x−k).

In this problem, we are shifting right by 3 units, so we substitute (x−3) for every x in the original equation:
g(x)=f(x−3)=1x−3+4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the transformation rules: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></math> shifts right, <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></math> shifts left, <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> shifts up, and <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi></math> shifts down.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
The system of equations below has no solution. What is the value of k?
kx+3y=12
4x+6y=20
questions.explanation: For a system to have no solution, the lines must be parallel, meaning their slopes are equal but intercepts differ. Rewrite the second equation: <math><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>20</mn></math> -> <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>10</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The slope is <math><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The first equation is <math><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></math> -> <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Equating slopes: <math><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> implies <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a system has no solution, the ratio of x-coefficients must equal the ratio of y-coefficients (<math><mfrac><mi>k</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math>).

questions.question: A radioactive substance decays such that its mass decreases by 15% every year. If the initial mass is 400 grams, which function <math><mi>m</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></math> models the mass in grams <math><mi>t</mi></math> years later?
questions.explanation: Decaying by 15% means 85% of the mass remains each year. The decay factor is <math><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.85</mn></math>. The model is <math><mtext>Initial</mtext><mo>×</mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>Rate</mtext><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, so <math><mn>400</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.85</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>t</mi></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential decay, the base is always (1 - rate). For growth, it is (1 + rate).

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels at a speed of 90 kilometers per hour. What is this speed in meters per second? (1 kilometer = 1,000 meters)
questions.explanation: Convert km to m: <math><mn>90</mn><mtext> km</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn><mtext> m</mtext></math>. Convert hours to seconds: <math><mn>1</mn><mtext> hour</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>600</mn><mtext> seconds</mtext></math>. Divide distance by time: <math><mfrac><mrow><mn>90</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>600</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math> meters per second.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use dimensional analysis (factor-label method) to track units and ensure they cancel out correctly.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='200' fill='white'/><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M 100,100 L 180,100 A 80,80 0 0,0 100,20 Z' fill='lightgray' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='90' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='185' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>A</text><text x='100' y='15' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>B</text><text x='140.0' y='115' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'>4</text><text x='120' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O and radius 4. A sector OAB is shaded. The sector is bounded by radius OA and radius OB. The central angle is labeled x°.
questions.question: The area of the shaded sector is <math><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. If the radius of the circle is <math><mn>4</mn></math>, what is the measure of the central angle <math><mi>x</mi></math> in degrees?
questions.explanation:
To find the central angle, we use the formula for the area of a sector:
Area=x360πr2

We are given the Area = 4π and the radius r=4. Substituting these values into the formula:
4π=x360π(42)

Simplify the equation:
4π=x36016π

Divide both sides by 16π:
4π16π=x360
14=x360

Solving for x:
x=3604=90.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the sector formulas. Area: <math><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Arc Length: <math><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>.

questions.question: What is the solution to the equation <math><msqrt><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn></msqrt><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 2 to both sides: <math><msqrt><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Square both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Subtract 13: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Verify: <math><msqrt><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn></msqrt><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Correct.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check for extraneous solutions when solving radical equations by plugging the answer back into the original equation.

questions.question: A shipping company charges a flat fee of $10 plus $0.50 per pound. If a customer wants to spend at most $40 on shipping, which inequality represents the maximum weight <math><mi>w</mi></math>, in pounds, they can ship?
questions.explanation: The cost is $10 (flat) + 0.50 (per pound <math><mi>w</mi></math>). Total cost is <math><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.50</mn><mi>w</mi></math>. 'At most' means less than or equal to <math><mo>≤</mo></math>. So, <math><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.50</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate key phrases literally: 'at most' becomes <math><mo>≤</mo></math>, 'at least' becomes <math><mo>≥</mo></math>.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> represents a parabola. If the vertex of the parabola is at <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and the graph passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute the vertex <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Substitute the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Simplify: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math> -> <math><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Subtract 7: <math><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Vertex form <math><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> is powerful. Plug in the vertex for <math><mi>h</mi></math> and <math><mi>k</mi></math>, then any other point for <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math> to find <math><mi>a</mi></math>.

questions.question: The equation of a circle in the xy-plane is <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Complete the square. Group x and y terms: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Add <math><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math> and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> to both sides: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. This becomes <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. The radius is <math><msqrt><mn>25</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To convert general circle equations to standard form, complete the square for both x and y variables simultaneously.

questions.question: A polynomial <math><mi>p</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> has a zero at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Which of the following must be a factor of <math><mi>p</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: According to the Factor Theorem, if <math><mi>p</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, then <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is a factor of the polynomial. Here, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, so the factor is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>)</mo></math>, which simplifies to <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Connect zeros (roots) directly to factors: Root <math><mi>k</mi></math> means factor <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math>.
